Hi, I'm Antonella and I'm a lead
technical recruiter. I have been working
in HR and recruitment for 8 years now
and almost four of them are in the video
game industry and I worked in different
companies and recruited for a huge
variety of different projects. And today
I want to talk about what happens in
behind the scenes of the recruitment
process. One of the most common concerns
for junior candidates is to feel
underestimated during the recruitment
process. But hey, if a company's
interviewing you is because they
definitely saw an alignment between your
skills and their [music] needs. Also, a
company is not just looking to hire for
someone that can complete tasks, [music]
but also for someone that can
communicate effectively and work
together with the whole team. So, how
would you showcase all of that during
the recruitment process? But more
specifically, how would you answer
complex interview questions? And I'm not
just talking about yes or no questions,
but questions like, for example, can you
tell me about the most challenging
project that you worked in the past? So
those questions can be answered by using
the STAR method. What exactly is the
STAR method? Well, it's a tool that will
help you architect [music] the way that
you deliver information. So let's break
it down. It consists on four steps.
[music] And the first step is the S that
stands for situation. [music] So here
what you want to do is provide a little
bit of context of the project that
you're going to be talking about. So for
example, if it's a video game, you can
mention the genre. You can also mention
the engine that you are using and the
platform or platforms where the game was
going to be released. Now moving on to a
second step, we have the T. That's stand
chance for task. So if you were working
with a whole team, you can definitely
cover what was expected from the team.
[music] But it's very important that you
mention and you highlight your personal
tasks and responsibilities.
Now moving on to a third step of the
method, we have the A that stands for
action. And this is the longest part of
the method. Here what you want to cover
is all the steps that you took to
address the situation. And you can also
mention any additional tools or
softwares that you are using. And
finally [music] for the fourth step we
have the R that stands for result. Here
basically you want to talk about the
outcome of all of your efforts. And you
can also mention two things. [music] If
you have any measurable results or
metrics and one of my favorite ones, you
can also talk about all the lessons that
you learned while working on the
project. But the best advice that I can
give you is [music] to always be
yourself during the recruitment process.
I hope that helps.
